title: Introduction to ehymet
text: ehymet package (Epigraph-Hypograph based methodologies functional data) R package designed extend popular multivariate data analysis methodologies functional data using various indices. package introduces epigraph hypograph indices, along modified versions functional datasets one multiple dimensions. indices transform functional dataset multivariate one, enabling application existing multivariate data analysis methods. information theory behind methodologies can found following papers: Bel√©n Pulido, Alba M. Franco-Pereira, Rosa E. Lillo (2023). ‚Äúfast epigraph hypograph-based approach clustering functional data.‚Äù Statistics Computing, 33, 36. doi: 10.1007/s11222-023-10213-7 Bel√©n Pulido, Alba M. Franco-Pereira, Rosa E. Lillo (2024). ‚ÄúClustering multivariate functional data using epigraph hypograph indices: case study Madrid air quality.‚Äù doi: 10.48550/arXiv.2307.16720

title: Introduction to ehymet
text: ehymet introduces two functions generate different Data Generation Processes (DGPs) functional data one multiple dimension. first function, sim_model_ex1, generate DGPs one dimension originally described (Flores, Lillo, Romo 2018). second function, sim_model_ex2, produces DGPs one two dimensions first introduced (Martino et al. 2019). functions useful simulating functional data test statistical methods understand behavior different models controlled conditions. two functions display different DGPs depending given parameters, different characteristics.

code: n <- 5 curves <- sim_model_ex1(n = n, i_sim = 1) dim(curves) #> [1] 10 30 library(tidyr) library(dplyr) library(ggplot2) library(ggsci) library(cowplot)  plot_curves <- function(curves, title = "", subtitle = "") {   data <- as.data.frame(curves) |>     mutate(curve_id = row_number())   n <- dim(curves)[1] / 2    data_long <- data |>     pivot_longer(       cols = -curve_id,       names_to = "point",       values_to = "value"     ) %>%     mutate(       point = as.numeric(sub("V", "", point)),       group = if_else(curve_id %in% 1:n, 1, 2)     )    ggplot(data_long, aes(x = point, y = value, group = curve_id, color = as.factor(group))) +     geom_line() +     labs(       title    = title,       subtitle = subtitle,       color    = "Group",       x        = "",       y        = ""     ) +     scale_color_d3() +     theme_half_open() +     theme(legend.position = "none") }  plot_curves(curves, title = "Type 1 DGPs", subtitle = "i_sim = 1")

title: Clustering through the epigraph and hypograph indices
text: One main utilities epigraph hypograph index able measure ``extremality‚Äô‚Äô curve respect bunch curves provide ordination curves top bottom vice-versa. EHyClus methodology clustering functional data based four steps: Smooth functional dataset. Apply indices data, first second derivatives. Apply classical multivariate clustering technique. Obtain clustering partition kk groups (kk fixed advanced). ehymet, function allows us perform process EHyClus. EHyClus function designed clustering functional datasets. input data can one-dimensional dataset, n√ópn \times p matrix, multidimensional one, n√óp√óqn \times p \times q array. function transforms initial dataset first smoothing data applying different indices analyzed first vignette epigraph, hypograph, modified versions, applies various clustering algorithms dataset. Indices one multiple dimension applied depending size input data. supports multiple clustering methods: hierarchical clustering (‚Äúhierarch‚Äù), k-means (‚Äúkmeans‚Äù), kernel k-means (‚Äúkkmeans‚Äù), spectral clustering (‚Äúspc‚Äù). Also, allows customization hierarchical clustering methods, distance metrics, kernels using parameters like l_dist_hierarch. smoothing, uses B-splines specified automatically selected number basis functions. check quality results, true labels provided, function can validate clustering results compute performance metrics purity, F-measure, Rand Index (RI). Also, records time taken clustering method, case want measure case wanting know trade-results execution time

title: Clustering through the epigraph and hypograph indices
text: vars_combinations = "auto", EHyClus automatically select optimal combination variables data-driven approach. process works comprised two main steps: first step focuses identifying variables show enough variation meaningful discriminators. variable, function calculates many unique values contains relative total number observations. variables ratio exceeds 50% retained. ensures focus variables sufficient variation useful distinguishing different groups. second step deals redundancy selected variables. , multiple variables essentially contain information won‚Äôt improve clustering results. address , function examines correlated remaining variables . two variables show correlation higher 0.75, keep one . Specifically, look correlated variable variables average, remove one shows higher average correlation. helps ensure final set variables provides unique, non-redundant information clustering. ‚Äôs example using automatic variable selection:
code: # Generate sample data n <- 50 curves <- sim_model_ex2(n = n, i_sim = 4) true_labels <- c(rep(1, n), rep(2, n))  # Use automatic variable selection res_auto <- EHyClus(curves,                      vars_combinations = "auto",                     true_labels = true_labels)  # Look at which variables were selected attr(res_auto, "vars_combinations")[[1]] #> [1] "ddtaMEI"  "dtaMHI"   "ddtaMHI"  "d2dtaMHI"

what: Methodologies for Functional Data Based on the Epigraph and Hypograph Indices
title: Methodologies for Functional Data Based on the Epigraph and Hypograph Indices
text: ehymet package define epigraph, hypograph modified versions functional datasets one multiple dimensions. indices allow transform functional dataset multivariate one, usual clustering techniques can applied. package implements EHyClus method clustering functional data one multiple dimension.

code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("bpulidob/ehymet")

what: Clustering using Epigraph and Hypograph indices ‚Äî EHyClus
title: Clustering using Epigraph and Hypograph indices ‚Äî EHyClus
text: creates multivariate dataset containing epigraph, hypograph /modified versions curves derivatives perform hierarchical clustering, kmeans, kernel kmeans, spectral clustering

title: Clustering using Epigraph and Hypograph indices ‚Äî EHyClus
code: EHyClus(   curves,   vars_combinations,   k = 30,   n_clusters = 2,   bs = "cr",   clustering_methods = c("hierarch", "kmeans", "kkmeans", "spc"),   l_method_hierarch = c("single", "complete", "average", "centroid", "ward.D2"),   l_dist_hierarch = c("euclidean", "manhattan"),   l_dist_kmeans = c("euclidean", "mahalanobis"),   l_kernel = c("rbfdot", "polydot"),   true_labels = NULL,   only_best = FALSE,   verbose = FALSE,   n_cores = 1,   ... )

title: Clustering using Epigraph and Hypograph indices ‚Äî EHyClus
text: curves Dataset containing curves apply clustering algorithm. functional dataset can one dimensional (\(n \times p\)) \(n\) number curves p number time points, multidimensional (\(n \times p \times q\)) \(q\) represents number dimensions data vars_combinations list,  element list atomic vector strings names variables. Combinations non-valid variable names discarded. list non-named, names variables set vars1, ..., varsk, k number elements vars_combinations. "auto" provided, unique combination variable found. provided, generic combinations variables used. uni-dimensional multi-dimensional problems. k Number basis functions B-splines. equals 0, number basis functions automatically selected. n_clusters Number clusters generate. bs two letter character string indicating (penalized) smoothing basis use. See smooth.terms. clustering_methods character vector specifying least one following clustering methods computed: "hierarch", "kmeans", "kkmeans" "spc". l_method_hierarch list clustering methods hierarchical clustering. l_dist_hierarch list distances hierarchical clustering. l_dist_kmeans list distances kmeans clustering. l_kernel list kernels kkmeans spc. true_labels Numeric vector true labels validation. provided, evaluation metrics computed final result. only_best logical value. TRUE true_labels provided, function return result best clustering method based Rand Index. Defaults FALSE. verbose TRUE, function print logs execution clustering methods. Defaults FALSE. n_cores Number cores parallel computation. 1 default, mean parallel execution. Must integer number greater 1. ... Additional arguments tfb. See tfb.

title: Clustering using Epigraph and Hypograph indices ‚Äî EHyClus
text: list containing clustering partition method indices combination , true_labels provided data frame containing time elapsed obtaining clustering partition indices dataset methodology. Also, number generated clusters combinations variables used can seen attributes object.

See smooth.terms. indices Set indices applied dataset. EI, HI, MEI MHI. n_cores Number cores parallel computation. 1 default, mean parallel execution. Must integer number greater 1. ... Additional arguments tfb. See tfb.

what: Function for generating functional data in one dimension ‚Äî sim_model_ex1
title: Function for generating functional data in one dimension ‚Äî sim_model_ex1
text: dataset 2 groups n curves , defined interval \(t=[0, 1]\) p equidistant points. first n curves generated fron following model \(X_1(t)=E_1(t)+e(t)\) \(E_1(t)=E_1(X(t))=30t^{ \frac{3}{2}}(1-t)\) mean function \(e(t)\) centered Gaussian process covariance matrix \(Cov(e(t_i),e(t_j))=0.3 \exp(-\frac{\lvert t_i-t_j \rvert}{0.3})\) remaining 50 functions generated model i_sim i_sim \(\\{1, \ldots, 8\}.\) first three models contain changes mean, covariance matrix change. Model 4 5 obtained multiplying covariance matrix constant. Model 6 obtained adding \(E_1(t)\) centered Gaussian process \(h(t)\) whose covariance matrix given \(Cov(e(t_i),e(t_j))=0.5 \exp (-\frac{\lvert t_i-t_j\rvert}{0.2})\). Model 7 8 obtained different mean function. Model 1. \(X_1(t)=30t^{\frac{3}{2}}(1-t)+0.5+e(t).\) Model 2. \(X_2(t)=30t^{\frac{3}{2}}(1-t)+0.75+e(t).\) Model 3. \(X_3(t)=30t^{\frac{3}{2}}(1-t)+1+e(t).\) Model 4. \(X_4(t)=30t^{\frac{3}{2}}(1-t)+2 e(t).\) Model 5. \(X_5(t)=30t^{\frac{3}{2}}(1-t)+0.25 e(t).\) Model 6. \(X_6(t)=30t^{\frac{3}{2}}(1-t)+ h(t).\) Model 7. \(X_7(t)=30t{(1-t)}^2+ h(t).\) Model 8. \(X_8(t)=30t{(1-t)}^2+ e(t).\)
